summary: The largest land mammal on Earth, African elephants play a vital role in shaping their ecosystems but face major threats from poaching and habitat loss.
Found only on the island of Sumatra, these intelligent primates are critically endangered due to deforestation and illegal hunting.
Known for its hooked upper lip, the black rhino has been pushed to the brink by poaching for its horn despite strong conservation efforts.
One of the rarest turtles on Earth, with only a few individuals known to exist, making its survival extremely uncertain.
The world’s rarest marine mammal, the vaquita is on the edge of extinction due to illegal fishing in the Gulf of California.
Living high in central Africa’s forests, mountain gorillas have rebounded thanks to conservation but remain endangered from poaching and disease.
The elusive snow leopard roams the mountains of Central Asia, threatened by habitat loss and human-wildlife conflict.
These graceful marine turtles are vital to ocean ecosystems but suffer from pollution, bycatch, and egg poaching.
Famous for its beautiful shell, the hawksbill turtle is critically endangered due to illegal trade and coral reef destruction.
Smaller than its African cousin, the Asian elephant faces habitat fragmentation and conflict with humans across South Asia.
One of the rarest big cats, the Amur leopard survives in the cold forests of eastern Russia with only a few dozen individuals remaining.
A massive river predator native to the Orinoco Basin, nearly hunted to extinction for its hide but now slowly recovering.
Covered in keratin scales, this pangolin is heavily trafficked for traditional medicine and meat, making it highly endangered.
A dazzling blue tarantula found only in a small forest area of India, threatened by habitat destruction and illegal pet trade.
The red panda, with its fiery fur and gentle nature, depends on Himalayan forests now shrinking from human expansion.
A unique dolphin that lives in rivers and coastal waters, threatened by fishing nets and water pollution.
Once widespread across Asia, the Asiatic lion now survives only in India’s Gir Forest, protected by ongoing conservation work.
A rare Indian tarantula with striking patterns, critically endangered due to deforestation and pet trade collection.
The largest sea turtle species, known for its leathery shell, faces grave threats from fishing gear and plastic pollution.
With fewer than 80 individuals remaining, the Javan rhino is one of the rarest mammals on Earth, surviving only in one national park.
